151194287.review:
You know, this 'game' is a vivid example of modern art. When a dude sticks banana to a wall and calls it a high art. And then, there are also hundreds of aesthetes and refined intellectuals nearby, who examine this 'art' via their monocles, just to make categorical proclamation: YES! True art! Unprecedented! Brave! Innovative!

And of course, there are common people as well. Thousands of common bystanders, who have no idea what's going on here. But since everyone around calls it an art, they are either too shy or too scared to admit that they do not see anything brilliant here. What if the game is too intellectual and they are simply not wise enough to understand this work of art?

But I'm totally shameless bastard. If I do not see or do not understand something - I'll admit it right away. People in their positive reviews may troll or hide behind abstruse and philosophical statements as much as they want. But if you put off your rainbow glasses, you will see that this 'game' is absolutely hollow inside.

I can already see how these refined connoisseurs are trying to poke their golden canes into my face, claiming that it is more than a mere game - it's an [b] Experience! [/b] Senseless wandering in the same empty corridors dozens of times, just to trigger another ending - that's your experience.

Oh man, what an absolutely fascinating endings await you. For example, you casually walk into the room and just get locked. That's an ending. Very deep, right? How about this one: you decide to go down to parking lot, then - Bam! Black screen, you are dead and random woman stands at your body. Very thought provoking, don't you think so? Other endings are just as great.

I unlocked 6-9 endings I guess. I can't say for sure because it is hard to identify if it really was an ending or not. For example, in one case you get locked in a room and get some spiteful comment from the narrator. In another case - you get locked, but nothing happens. Was it bug? Feature? Level 9000 post meta irony? - no idea. And honestly, no desire to wander in these corridors again. Have you ever encountered bugs in any other game? Got soft locked or stuck in a texture/wall/closed room? Turns out it should be considered as something deep, philosophical or thought provoking.

Also, there is no reasonable way to discover these endings - all you have to do, just wander around making random choices, until you trigger another narrator's commentary. Oh, sorry, did I say choices? All you choose here in most cases, just what door to enter. 

You choose the door on the right, move forward, walk around - bad ending. You choose door on the right, then come back and choose the one on the left - 'wife' ending. You go down to parking lot - you are dead. You go upstairs to the 'boss' - you are on the way to 'right' ending. Then, out of blue, the game gives you an option to choose escape/suicide ending (just like in Portal)... Why here? Why now? What's so special about this bunch of 'choices'? - No idea.

Won't deny, initially it seemed rather intriguing. Sometimes even funny. But everything became dull or even annoying very soon. As if you are listening some not very funny stand up comic. From time to time you get a good joke here and there, but most of the time you put forced smile on your face, just out of politeness.

Narrator's voice is so overconfident and so patronizing, while the game has nothing that could justify such bravado. No coherent story, no interesting characters, no gameplay, no puzzles... The game boasts via achievements how 'they disabled jumping', but it seems like they also disabled any possible interactivity here. Source engine, but nothing to interact with. 

Conclusion. Stanley Parable has some good ideas. In certain endings/sketches you can really feel how these ideas could grow into something bigger or even in separate game. Unfortunately these ideas just remained as ideas without any meaningful development. If you will evaluate the game for what it actually is, instead of what you were told it is - you will see that it is just few hours of boring walking-talking and few lulz.

151017178.review:
Decided to come back to this game -- 100%ing the achievements here seemed like a good way to pass some of the now-nine years I've got until I obtain Super Go Outside in Ultra Deluxe.

I was expecting it to still be good, but to also feel limited by the lack of Hashtag New Content™ available in UD. Instead, I obtained a newfound love for this game; the meta-commentary on video game narratives (including its own, obviously), the push-and-pull between Stanley, The Narrator and even the player themselves -- and of course the Broom Closet Ending -- were all still as engaging as I remembered and more. If you haven't played this game yet or, like me, need to scratch an itch for The Stanley Parable without waiting 10 years, I sincerely recommend picking it up.

P.S.: The 71 hours is from me repeatedly failing to get the Commitment achievement these past couple of weeks. I could probably play it for that amount of time legit though, to be honest.

150269769.review:
[h1] [b] [i] A game that plays you more than you play it [/i] [/b] [/h1]

[h1] [b] [i] ★★★★★★★★★★ [/i] [/b] [/h1]

If I were to be asked about a singular video-game that truly and best encapsulates the essence of what makes video-games as a whole a truly unique type of art, it would be Stanley Parable. Many games, both future and past, claim that they are the most "original" or "unique" or "never-seen-before" but none have been able to deliver on it in the way this masterpiece has. Welcome to Stanley Parable, an unassuming, seemingly boringly normal game that, after a closer look, is experience like no other, for you can never be sure, how much you are playing it and how much it is playing you. Only one way to find out.

[h1] [i] “But they didn't understand that the game was never meant to be funny, it was meant to have a point. It was meant to speak to the human condition. 'But where are the jokes? Where are the jokes?' they bemoaned. They screamed, they gnashed their teeth and said 'entertain us'. It wasn't enough, they had to leave their pathetic little thumbs down review. But then 'He's talking too much' they said 'First, he didn't entertain us and now he won't shut up!' It's the inconsistency, it's the lack of accountability! It's the unwillingness to examine with an uncompromising heart the words that they are speaking into the world. As though there were no consequences for a lack of cohesion in one's assessment of others!” [/i] [/h1]

Stanley Parable is game that impossible to begin to describe. Closest to it is to imagine Valve's Portal, set in an office environment, minus the portal gun and with GladOS replaced by a confused story-teller shaping the story based on your inputs and one who genuinely means well but one who messes up frequently. I love how this is, in essence, a D&D office adventure with the most confused (yet also the most intriguing) DM you can imagine. It's just something else, honestly.

The main aspect that made Stanley Parable the legend it is today is, without a doubt, its sheer amount of choices and branching paths. You can at any point decide to go off narrator's script and the game (and in that vein, him) will adapt - for better or for worse. Pair that with brilliantly written monologue captivatingly narrated by the talented Kevan Brighting and what you get is a game that you WILL want to restart over and over and over, just to see how you can break it or break narrator's spirit but scr*wing up every single one of his requests. For the end is never the end...

If there was ever a video-game I think I could recommend to absolutely anyone, Stanley Parable would be it. You can know comprehend it's both intended and unintended genius until you try it out for yourself.

149986393.review:
The Stanley Parable is an incredibly witty and insightful experience that you must play. I truly recommend this game because this is the story of a man named Stanley. Stanley worked for a company in a big building where he was Employee #427. Employee #427's job was simple: he sat at his desk in Room 427 and he pushed buttons on a keyboard. Orders came to him through a monitor on his desk telling him what buttons to push, how long to push them, and in what order. This is what Employee #427 did every day of every month of every year, and although others may have considered it soul rending, Stanley relished every moment that the orders came in, as though he had been made exactly for this job. And Stanley was happy. And then one day, something very peculiar happened. Something that would forever change Stanley; Something he would never quite forget. He had been at his desk for nearly an hour when he had realized not one single order had arrived on the monitor for him to follow. No one had shown up to give him instructions, call a meeting, or even say 'hi'. Never in all his years at the company had this happened, this complete isolation. Something was very clearly wrong. Shocked, frozen solid, Stanley found himself unable to move for the longest time. But as he came to his wits and regained his senses, he got up from his desk and stepped out of his office.

Thank you for reading my original, in-depth analysis of this classic game that you've never heard word-for-word before! :D

148636172.review:
This is a user submitted review of a game called The Stanley Parable.

In this read the user rasterman7 decided to inform other users of the platform about the marvels of the aforementioned game. Its original extracts had taken immaculate details of the office layout and walking gameplay but in later versions he decided that they didn't serve much of a purpose to let new players know about the game. So then he decided to rewrite it.

Taking caution not to reveal what kind of thrilling events may partake the story, he simply mentioned the atmosphere and the narrator's voice which were the first things that came to mind. The latter was curiously enough sounding in his mind at the time of writing this and it sometimes made some humorous and/or dark remarks about an otherwise innocuous game.

Not sure what else to say, he pondered over the calendar, planning his move for the next Tuesday where he would be able to finally get that pesky achievement he had been craving for some time. Realizing that his thoughts were now being conveyed through his notes, he found it strange and a bit concerning. Nevertheless he paid no mind to them as the review was just about done at this point.

146582664.review:
10/10 Would play again. I've watched so many playthroughs of this game since it came out and I decided to finally play it for myself. Honestly, even though I've now gone through all of the endings (yes, including the super tedious baby game) I still find myself wanting to play it again. I think the simplicity of it really appeals to me. I walk the same path over and over, but i still stop to let the narrator finish narrating. Now, as for whether I do that for the sake of not breaking the ambiance or if I do it because I like the voice, that's a question for another day. 

I would 100% recommend this to my friends if I wasn't already the only one in my friend group who hasn't played it yet... so I guess all that I can do now is recommend it to you! If you enjoy listening to a middle-aged man getting frustrated at you for not following directions, this is the game for you! Inversely, if you enjoy following the instructions of a middle-aged man, this game could also fit your standards!

(This is my first ever review, please don't bash me too hard lmao)

146554224.review:
I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THE STANLEY PARABLE.

I was excited to play this game when I found out my dad owned it. I had watched an hour and 11 minutes of Markipliers full game-play of The Stanley Parable Ultra Deluxe, then some of his older game-play videos of this original version. I fell in love immediately.

I remember sometime in the past, hearing my father mention getting the "Go Outside" achievement on The Stanley Parable. I had no clue what it was at the time, but the memory resurfaced very recently (as in like, 3 or 4 days ago recently) when I put two and two together. Wow, I actually use my braincells? Unfathomable. Moving along, this game is absolutely wonderful.

First off, the concept is just absolutely incredible. I know there are many parable games, but I'd personally say The Stanley Parable takes it to a whole other LEVEL with how just- AWESOME it is! And the amount of endings? That's true just... artwork! Not to mention Kevan's absolutely wonderful voice acting of the Narrator? How does The Stanley Parable have absolutely everything I've ever wanted... in one game alone?

Also, god I can't even express the love I have for the more serious endings. The Zending? Made me cry. Like, genuine, not kidding, made me cry. That's how you can tell its a good game, you know? An ending of a parable game getting you so worked up you cry, hah.

I love the relationship between the Narrator and Stanley. It's almost like a friendly rivalry in a sense, if you put it into words, except you really can't. Another thing, that's how you know it's good writing, when there's something you aren't even able to describe, ya know what I mean? 
I've barely mentioned The Stanley Parable ; Ultra Deluxe Edition this whole review, but that does make sense, as you know, I am currently reviewing specifically The Stanley Parable. 

But, The Stanley Parable ; Ultra Deluxe? Absolutely awesome. The amount of more endings it introduced with the bucket is awesome, even if in my own opinion some of the re-writings of classic endings (I say this like I played it in 2013) were kind of shitty, it is overall awesome to get so much more content. SPEAKING OF CONTENT the whole new content with the Narrator was hilarious- but I'm straying from the review of The Stanley Parable if I go in depth, because then it would really be a review of The Stanley Parable ; Ultra Deluxe, which I don't even own, so I'll stop myself there.

Even though I did stop myself describing The Stanley Parable ; Ultra Deluxe in detail, does not mean that is the end of it's section in this review. It was a wonderful re-release; actually I'd say one of the best in video game history (but I'm extremely bias because it is the way I found The Stanley Parable, and not to mention it is also my favorite re-release in video game history), so I'll leave it at just saying it, truly, didn't disappoint.

I don't know how to end this review- so I suppose I'll end it here as of now. I've only played 20 hours of the game as of now, but I'm sure that I'll have many more soon. I hope you enjoyed reading this, cause I enjoyed writing this! I'll probably update this minorly (or majorly, it depends) in the future, but I don't think my opinion will change of this game at all.

I love The Stanley Parable. That's my conclusion of this review. Goodbye for now, Steam reviews of The Stanley Parable!

146457506.review:
If you haven't heard of this game, positively or negatively, I can only assume you've only just now gained sentience and were born after it came out. Sarcastic, witty, very unserious in how it perceives itself, you can most accurately compare this game to old-school shitposting where the person making the post might just be a self-loathing jester.

This game plays a lot with how players usually interact with games, narrative choices, logical decissions, ... but also with how we as humans often react to vague demands, direct demands, threatening demands, ... In the end, you will want to be as random as possible, just for the sheer joy of seeing the narrator spiral into a nigh-neverending pit of self-doubt, madness, and agony. In the end, you will gladly want this - trust me.

Recommended!

No, a definite no. 
A few chuckles till the humour gets childish, then slight  praise for the dev's intention, then disbelief at the thought of the mind numbing boredom if I tried to stick with it. 
It's pretentious, and the narrator is constantly patronising. Achievement 430 (nearly all achievements are impossible to get) [spoiler]..knock on door 430 five times. No, I don't feel you really care so knock on it twenty times, no fifty, now knock on 417 ten times, and so on and on....and on. [/spoiler]
And I have nothing against walking simulators, some of my favourite games are ws. But walking around a set of offices again and again, with the odd maintenance room to break up the monotony? Oh, put me out of my misery. [spoiler] Which the narrator does with a restart, time after time. [/spoiler]
The game is not intellectual,  I found it silly, and ultimately, boring.

144533132.review:
This game has aged very poorly, and anyone looking to buy it should probably just grab Ultra Deluxe, the remake / remaster. This is no great shame on the Stanley Parable itself, but rather the fact that many future titles have built upon and expanded the 'meta-narative' genre which the Stanley Parable had brought into the limelight.

Gameplay-wise, I honestly found both "Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist" and "The Beginners Guide" more interesting, but I feel that should be no surprise given that they're later releases from the same dev team. 

Still, the game (specifically, this version of the game) is worth playing through if you find it sitting in the depths of your steam library waiting to be revisited, as I have.

142763721.review:
At a time when video games were still largely just straightforward modernist affairs, The Stanley Parable was a mind blowing experience. The post-modern deconstructionist approach had never really been done before, least of all with the witty irreverence that the writer and narrator brought to this experience.

This was one of the first big games to really unravel and explore the idea of video game logic in a humorous in-game metamodern style. The game was so far ahead of the curve and the self referential comedic story telling had such an impact that has gone on to influence many designers in the modern space. A genuinely impressive piece of gaming history.

Either way if you have never played it its worth picking up and adding to your backlog.

140192497.review:
In the words of Peter Griffin, "Freakin' sweet!" The Stanley Parable is like a mash-up of all the hilarious moments from Family Guy. It's a mind-bending adventure that takes you on a wild ride through an office building, just like that time Peter became a private investigator in "Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story."

As you play through The Stanley Parable, you'll feel like you're living in Quahog, with all the quirky characters and absurd situations. It's like that time Peter and the gang found a talking tree in the woods and had to save it from being cut down in "Road to the Multiverse." You never know what's coming next, and that's what makes it so frickin' hilarious.

The game is full of choices, just like when Peter had to decide between a boat and a mystery box in "I'm Peter, Hear Me Roar." Each decision you make leads you down a different path, and just like in that episode, you never know if you made the right choice until it's too late. It's like living out a Family Guy episode in real time!

One of the best parts of The Stanley Parable is the narrator. He's like Stewie, always narrating and commenting on your every move. It's like when Stewie narrated Brian's life in "Brian Griffin's House of Payne." The narrator in The Stanley Parable guides you through the game, but just like Stewie, he can also mess with you and lead you into hilarious and unexpected situations.

The humor in The Stanley Parable is off-the-charts, just like when Peter had that epic fight with the giant chicken. It's a rollercoaster of laughs, like when Peter joined the rodeo and became a bull rider in "Save the Clam." The game constantly breaks the fourth wall and challenges your expectations, just like Family Guy always does.

In conclusion, The Stanley Parable is a frickin' awesome adventure that will keep you laughing and guessing at every turn. It's like having your own Family Guy episode that you get to play and control. So grab your Pawtucket Patriot Ale and get ready for a wild ride that'll have you saying, "Freakin' sweet!"

140007766.review:
The Stanley Parable: A Meta-Narrative Masterpiece

Rating: ★★★★★

The Stanley Parable is a thought-provoking and innovative game that challenges the very concept of interactive storytelling. With its clever writing, branching paths, and meta-commentary on player agency, this game pushes the boundaries of the medium, leaving players questioning their choices and the nature of their own free will.

At its core, The Stanley Parable is an exploration of choice and control. Players assume the role of Stanley, an office worker who finds himself in a seemingly ordinary office environment. As Stanley, you are guided by a witty and omnipresent narrator, whose every word serves to influence and manipulate your actions. The brilliance of the game lies in the multitude of choices presented to the player, each with unpredictable consequences and narratives that twist and turn in unexpected ways.

The writing in The Stanley Parable is exceptional. The narrator's voice, delivered with impeccable timing and tone, adds a layer of dark humor and intrigue to the experience. The game's dialogue is filled with existential musings, philosophical ponderings, and self-aware commentary that constantly challenges the player's perception of their role and the nature of the game itself. It is a narrative tour de force that rewards multiple playthroughs, as each path offers unique insights and revelations.

The game's visual design is minimalistic yet effective. The stark office environments, with their repetitive corridors and monotonous color schemes, serve as a backdrop to the mind-bending narrative. The attention to detail in each scene, coupled with the occasional surreal moments, adds to the atmosphere of mystery and disorientation.

The Stanley Parable thrives on its branching paths and multiple endings. Each decision you make branches the story in new and unexpected directions, leading to a wide variety of outcomes. The game deliberately plays with your expectations, subverting traditional storytelling conventions and defying the constraints of linear narratives. It invites experimentation, curiosity, and exploration, as you attempt to uncover the various hidden endings and secrets that lie within the game's intricate web of choices.

One potential downside for some players is the lack of traditional gameplay elements. The Stanley Parable focuses more on interactive storytelling and exploration rather than action or puzzle-solving. It is an experience that prioritizes narrative and player agency over traditional game mechanics. However, for those who appreciate thought-provoking experiences and unconventional storytelling, this approach becomes one of the game's greatest strengths.

In conclusion, The Stanley Parable is an exceptional game that challenges the very notion of player agency and narrative design. Its clever writing, branching paths, and meta-commentary on choice and control create a truly unique and immersive experience. The game's thought-provoking nature lingers long after you've finished playing, sparking discussions and introspection. If you're seeking a game that defies conventions and offers an intellectual journey, The Stanley Parable is an absolute must-play. Prepare to question everything you thought you knew about video game storytelling.

137692491.review:
Here are some reasons why I think The Stanley Parable is a great game:

    1. unique gameplay: The Stanley Parable is not a typical game, but an interactive experience that takes the player into a world where every decision made has a direct impact on the course of the story. There are many different paths and endings to explore, making the game an unparalleled experience.

    2. wonderful narration: the narrative voice in The Stanley Parable is absolutely superb and captures the mood of the game perfectly. It guides the player through the story with an intensity and irony rarely found in other games.

    3. humorous atmosphere: the game is humorous, with many funny and quirky moments that always made me laugh. The surprises and twists that occur in the game make it extremely entertaining and create a pleasant atmosphere.

    4. compelling graphics: The graphics of The Stanley Parable are simple but very effective. It uses a minimalist aesthetic to create a unique atmosphere that perfectly matches the experience of the game.

    5. No limitations: One of the best things about The Stanley Parable is that there are no restrictions. The player can explore the world however they want without having to worry about limits or game mechanics.

    Overall, I think The Stanley Parable is a fantastic game that combines unique gameplay, wonderful narrative, humorous atmosphere and compelling graphics. It is an unforgettable experience that I would recommend to any gamer looking for something completely new and unconventional.

137388701.review:
I’ll start off by saying that both versions of The Stanley Parable, particularly Ultra Deluxe, are best experienced blind, so consider this 99% spoiler free. As a Switch owner of Ultra Deluxe, consider this a semi-short review/description of both versions this time around.

To describe it in a few, easy-to-remember sentences, The Stanley Parable is a first-person exploration game. Well–actually, far more of an experience than a game, being a blend of humor and self-awareness with an equal amount of dread, heart, and emotionality. Like most games in its nature, TSP has many moments left to interpretation. Very, VERY little is ‘explained’ per say, and that is one of its best traits; everyone will come out of the same ending differently. Especially so with Ultra Deluxe’s new content, which creates an even bigger blend between, let’s say, ‘treats and trauma’ in a way I love dearly.
Let’s not even forget to mention the incredible Kevan Brighting as The Narrator, who I very much know is the highlight for many players. For good reason.

So, how shall you and a close mutual play this game? In my opinion, play it by yourself on the console of your choosing–with you in complete silence–and when you’re done, show it to a friend who also hasn’t played it (If you liked it, of course). Let the The Stanley Parable guide you, then let yourself become the guide.

The Stanley Parable (And Ultra Deluxe all the more) is a passion project, and I will forever see it as such. Everyone involved is incredibly talented, and I wish everyone the best.
From the ashes of depravity rises the phoenix of quality.

136759117.review:
I had such a great laugh at my own expanse. How charming it was to be made fun of in so many distinctive ways in response to my shenanigans! I enjoyed it greatly. There are also so many secret ways of going for different scenarios - some very, very well hidden. It's fun to explore the options and see what you get. And sometimes what you get is entirely unexpected but weirdly logical in a nonsensical way. I was laughing so much following some of that bonkers logic, as if tracking The Line™. The game within the game was also so out of the blue - such a neat surprise!
Although, pssst, you know. "The broom closet ending was my favourite"! I DO hope my friends will find it concerning, yes indeed. I was having a blast sitting with the brooms, just vibing. Did you really had to wall it off? Such trickery!
Honestly though, this game was a delight. You might want to give it a go to brighten your mood.

136557769.review: I really wanted to like The Stanley Parable and I fully expected that I would (I mean, obviously, otherwise I wouldn't have bought it). I suspect this is the type of game that either totally clicks for you or seems like a complete waste of time. Unfortunately for me, I fall into the latter group. I didn't find it to be particularly funny, interesting, exciting, or engaging, and the commentary is very...mid. Perhaps it hasn't aged all that well given I played it a decade after its release and the ideas contemplated throughout the gameplay aren't super original (IMHO). All this being said, I know I didn't see every possible ending, but I'm also not motivated enough to do so. The game isn't [i]bad[/i] per se, I just wouldn't want a friend to buy it on my recommendation (or, at the very least, would recommend doing so at a heavy discount for the ~experience~ of playing a game that can be completed in ~260 seconds). It is all just [i]fine[/i].

136489645.review: By this point, you should really get the Ultra Deluxe version instead of the 2013 release. But this has been one of my all-time favorites for over a decade now. It's a little scary, a little sweet, and endlessly playful. It's got a wit that ranges from deeply dry to enormously silly, and you'll always feel a little unsure if you've entirely plumbed its depths. Whether you end up rethinking entirely how you engage with games, or just leave with a light chuckle, this is an easy purchase that belongs in most steam libraries.

135553623.review:
"The Stanley Parable" is a unique and intriguing game that offers a thought-provoking and humorous commentary on the nature of choice, control, and free will. The game's narrative structure is non-linear and unpredictable, allowing players to explore various branching paths and endings based on their decisions and actions.

One of the standout features of the game is its clever use of narration and voice acting, which guides and comments on the player's choices and movements throughout the game. The narrator's voice is smooth, calming, and sometimes unsettling, adding an extra layer of depth and intrigue to the game's overall atmosphere.

Another strength of "The Stanley Parable" is its ability to challenge players' expectations and assumptions. The game constantly subverts and plays with traditional game mechanics and storytelling conventions, leading to some unexpected and hilarious moments. The game's witty and self-aware humor also adds to its overall charm and appeal.

While the game's graphics and gameplay mechanics are relatively simple, they serve as a fitting backdrop for the game's main focus on narrative and player choice. Additionally, the game's soundtrack is subtle but effective, adding to the game's overall ambiance and tone.

Overall, "The Stanley Parable" is a clever and engaging game that offers a unique and memorable experience. Its unconventional storytelling and gameplay make it a must-play for anyone interested in exploring the boundaries of interactive storytelling and game design.

134322688.review:
The Stanley Parable is a story-based video game designed and written by developers Davey Wreden and William Pugh. The game carries themes such as choice in video games, the relationship between a game creator and player, and predestination/fate.

In the game, the player guides a silent protagonist named Stanley alongside narration by British actor Kevan Brighting. As the story progresses, the player is confronted with diverging pathways. The player may contradict the narrator's directions, which if disobeyed will then be incorporated into the story. Depending on the choices made, the player will encounter different endings before the game resets to the beginning.

The Stanley Parable was originally released on 31 July 2011, as a free modification for Half-Life 2 by Wreden. Together with Pugh, Wreden later released a stand-alone remake using the Source engine under the Galactic Cafe studio name. The remake recreated many of the original mod's choices while adding new areas and story pathways, as well as overhauling the game's graphics entirely. It was announced and approved via Steam Greenlight in 2012, and was released on 17 October 2013, for Microsoft Windows. Later updates to the game added support for macOS on 19 December 2013, and for Linux on 9 September 2015. A further expanded edition titled The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe was released on 27 April 2022. It is available on consoles in addition to previously supported platforms and it includes additional content, as well as further refined graphics.

Both the original mod and its two remakes have received critical praise from journalists. Critics praised the game's narrative and commentary on player choice and decision-making

Now I spend my time wistfully wishing I made more money so I could gift this thing to every person I know on Steam. 10/10, highly recommend.

133768115.review:
The Stanley Parable" is a game that defies easy description. It's a narrative-driven experience that takes the player on a journey through an unusual and often surreal environment. The game's core mechanic revolves around a narrator who guides the player through the story, but it's up to the player to decide whether or not to follow his instructions.

One of the things that makes "The Stanley Parable" so interesting is its unpredictability. The game is full of surprises and unexpected twists, and it's impossible to know what's coming next. The game's story and world-building are top-notch, and the game's humor and personality shine through in every moment.

What's particularly impressive about "The Stanley Parable" is the way that it encourages players to think outside the box and experiment with different choices and paths. The game is designed to have multiple endings and paths to take, and the player's actions can drastically affect the story and its outcome.

"The Stanley Parable" is definitely worth checking out.

132578384.review:
1: playing the Stanley Parable is good for your mental health.
	The great thing about this game specifically is the narrator. He constantly speaks to you, or in the context of the game, “stanley”, and guides you along the way. His clear mental instability will make you feel better about your own life. Though there may be some emotional and quite frankly goofy and silly parts along the way, the second you close your computer those problems don’t exist anymore. The stanley parable is like a sadness sponge. It makes you a little bit sadder, then stops and takes some of the pre existing unhappiness with it when you stop playing.
Although it is a bit of an emotional roller coaster (as i previously mentioned), the narrator can still be a nice person. He is silly and quite frankly goofy at times. I think if he had a body or any physical form for that matter, the first thing he would do would be a very silly dance to the adventure line music. He is very nice. Well, sometimes. Other times he explodes you. But only if you deserve it.
Only if you deserve it.
2: It has something for everyone.
Do you like horror games? The whole game is eerie and uncomfortable at times, constantly making you wonder when the narrator will just snap and brutally murder you. He can. And has. Even the loading screen, reading “the end is never” over and over again is unsettling.
Do you like sweet calming games that bring you joy? As I have mentioned previously, the narrator brings joy and silliness. He is a very chipper fellow, who wants to share his story with you. Do not make him sad if you want him to stay silly. Warning: He will not stay silly when sad. He will get angry.
Like scythe, (the perfect book) it wonderfully mixes every genre. Aside from romance. Actually, there are enough narrator simps that I’d say it qualifies. The game has an ending for everyone. There are multiple endings, based on how you play. Pro tip- you have to get a little off track to get the fun endings! You have to be adventurous and also somewhat silly to correctly play.
You can play with friends. If they’re in your house or on call with you, of course, because stanley is the only player. The narrator makes the game worth playing, because of the sheer volume of goofiness he adds to the plot. Which he created. It is truly a game worth playing.

132527052.review:
[h1][b]Overall Recommendation: 8 Stanley’s out of 10[/b][/h1]

[b]This game was paid for on Humble Bundle via the “Humble Postmodern Bundle with Catherine Classic” bundle.[/b]

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Using the source engine the game has good but not fantastic graphics, similar to Half-Life 2 and other source games; the game looks good but don’t be expecting a graphical showcase, It looks good but don’t expect a 2022 high fidelity game.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The game uses the classic source engine movement similar to half-life 2 or Garry’s mod however also changes it, you can’t bunny hop or go into a fast paced sprint or even jump and that can be noticeable however the game is built around the artificial limitations to create a fun experience.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is an interesting look at storytelling, you have the choice to follow the Narrator or go your own path, its very fourth wall breaking story, especially for some of the achievements, however it is a really fun game and I can highly recommend it.

[h1]Hell Achievements[/h1]
There are some achievements that are grindy and then there are the hell achievements, the 430 achievement is on the grindy side however its still really fun however the “Go Outside” & “Commitment” achievements are hell achievements. For the “Go Outside” achievement you’re going to have to wait 5 years, I originally played a DRM Free version before bringing my save to steam so I got the achievement that way, however for the “Commitment” achievement here’s the recommendation; 
Start the game near midnight on Monday night, put your system into sleep/pause mode, start it back up at least 5 minutes before midnight on Tuesday, this will save energy while getting the achievement. If you don’t have a spare system on hand you can use a cloud service such as an AWS or Google Cloud instance running windows server 2022.

132503786.review: This review is about a game known simply as: The Stanley Parable. The Stanley Parable was released in 2013, yet it has timeless writing that picks apart the games industry with meta references applicable to games being released to this very day. Timeless is the key word in the multiple part equation that is the Stanley Parable's intent. It's comedy is so interconnected into the appeal of this game, the narrator himself is a game play stipulation, as well the game itself is a stipulation with how it uses your own personal exploration and curious sensibilities to progress further and further and achieve different endings. The Stanley Parable should go down in history as one of the boundary pushers that reinvents what a game can be and what a game should strive to be. Whether it be this version or Ultra Deluxe, invest in The Stanley Parable.

132448413.review:
This is the story of a man named Stanley.

Stanley worked for a company in a big building where he was Employee #427.

Employee #427's job was simple: he sat at his desk in Room 427 and he pushed buttons on a keyboard.

Orders came to him through a monitor on his desk telling him what buttons to push, how long to push them, and in what order.

This is what Employee #427 did every day of every month of every year, and although others may have considered it soul rending,

Stanley relished every moment that the orders came in, as though he had been made exactly for this job.

And Stanley was happy.

And then one day, something very peculiar happened.

Something that would forever change Stanley;

Something he would never quite forget.

He had been at his desk for nearly an hour when he had realized not one single order had arrived on the monitor for him to follow.

No one had shown up to give him instructions, call a meeting, or even say 'hi'. Never in all his years at the company had this happened, this complete isolation.

Something was very clearly wrong. Shocked, frozen solid, Stanley found himself unable to move for the longest time.

But as he came to his wits and regained his senses, he got up from his desk and stepped out of his office.

And that is how a legend was born.

131061344.review:
El caso de este juego es bastante curioso, la versión original empezo como un mod de Half Life 2 en el cual se trataba el tema de la libertad en los videojuegos y como realmente en un video juego toda "libertad" que se pueda tener en un video juego esta realmente limitada por las elecciones de los creadores del juego. Un video juego siempre esta limitado por mucho que lo oculte ya que hay tiempo y recursos limitados para programarlos, pero Stanley Parable te muestra esos muros y limites para ser apreciados para luego burlarse de ti en la cara.

Es dificil describir este juego, pero la magia esta en la relación del Narrador y  Stanley (o el jugador) que cambia dependiendo de practicamente cada elección tomada y un pequeño cambio puede descarrilar una sencilla historia sobre libertad completamente guiada a... muchas otras cosas que no tienen nada que ver.

Sin duda una experiencia que todo videojugador experimentado deberia de probar al menos una vez.

130445850.review:
This is a story of a man named Stanley.
Stanley was at home playing games, where he was at Apartment number 427.
Stanley's task was simple.
He sat at his desk in his gaming room pushing buttons to move his character.
Orders came to him from his brain, telling him what buttons to push, how long to push them, and in what order.
This is what Stanley did every day of every month of every year. And althought others might have considered it soul-winning, Stanley relished every moment he got a kill on CS:GO, as if he was been made exactly for this. And Stanley was happy.
And then one day something very peculiar happened.
Something that would forever change Stanley.
Something he would never quite forget.
A video popped up in his recommendations tab on YouTube with the name "Stanley Parable" wroten on it.
Stanley searched for it and bought the Stanley Parable, the game was so fun he couldn't leave his desk. He couldn't stop playing the Stanley Parable. He didn't blink one time at his sheer excitement.

129902012.review:
[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/221910/The_Stanley_Parable/]The Stanley Parable[/url][/b] is an interesting game about someone named Stanley, and the narrator of this humorous story. I enjoyed the choose-your-own-adventure aspect, the basic game mechanics, and varieties of styles used in the game.   

With that said, its flaw was being a little bit too short.  I started, finished, and saw all of the game endings over 7 hours today.  Replayability is minimal once you've beaten it, so I probably won't play this one again.  But I probably won't forget it because it was enjoyable in its own unique way, like [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/234/Portal_Bundle/]Portal[/url] or [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1049410/Superliminal/]Superliminal[/url] were.  

So, if you're interested in giving this game a chance, I would recommend waiting for a good discount to justify the short game-play.  But if you want a short enjoyable game right now, then any price will work!

[h1]8/10[/h1]

128535171.review:
If steam allowed a neutral opinion, I'd probably pick that instead. 

This game is a decade old, and it hasn't aged well. I'm sure it was incredibly novel when it dropped, but the years have past, and now it just feels incredibly... Pretentious. This game thinks it's a lot more clever than it really is.

I will admit that there were times it made me FEEL something, which is a huge compliment. There are moments of dealing with the narrator where you will question your own, real, life, and exactly how much control you or anyone else has in a capitalistic society. That part is great. But those times are few and far between.  

Buy on sale and experience it for yourself; certainly not worth $15 (as of December '22).

Honestly, the thumbs down was mostly for the dumb achievements. Getting the "Click on room 430 five times" achievement was one of the most condescending and gross moments in my entire gaming career. I don't know why they felt the need to belittle your attempts at 100%ing their game so much. It really made it feel like they didn't respect my time.

Just my measly .02 about people who are probably much more intelligent than me.

127935390.review:
One of the first, and definitely the most successful among metagames: games about games. The plot is essentially a game version of The Truman's Show, in which a bland character named Stanley, devoid of any uniqueness and described by the narrator as a mindless button-pusher, traverses through an empty office following a narration - the player though, in command of Stanley, can choose to deviate from the narrator's instructions, much to his humorous dismay.

The game's branching paths through this game convey humor, satire, discomfort and even psychological terror at times, quickly shifting from one to other as you replay numerous times. At the time, it provoked many unique feelings through its separate paths. It was a unique, ground-breaking experience at time of launch, even as a Half Life mod, now polished as a stand-alone game with extra content - not to mention the "sequel". It's short but it's plentiful of good content.

As of 2022, some of the plot twists may seem predictable, but that's certainly due to the influence this game had in the industry over 10 years ago. If you haven't yet experienced it, you're in for a treat, get it now. 10/10

127909078.review: This delightfully wry game has me cackling with glee while sitting in a broom closet and repeatedly trying to open the same locked door. 126950490.review:
The Stanley Parable is a game that I can recommend. However it is one of those games that is better if you experience with as little knowledge as possible. Spoilers below.

The Stanley Parable is a game about games. Using the framework of a walking simulator, the game sets up an exploration of the tug of war between a creator's desire to tell a linear story and a player's desire to go the other way, get off track with distractions, and generally use the power as a player to disrupt the themes and seriousness of a narrative. After an introduction to the world and a quick walk through some office spaces, the narrator states "When Stanley came to a set of two open doors, he entered the door on his left." However, you the player have just entered the room and both doors are open. This room is the start of your path of choices of following the story or diverting from it. The loop of the game is exploring all the various pathways that are the results of this room.

The game is narrated by Kevan Brighting and makes the game far more memorable with his outstanding voice acting performance. To do a convoluted set of actions or have random chance produce a new spoken sentence is a rewarding experience.

This game is quite special to me as something that has made me think about how games are designed and created and what it means to interface with them.

125784391.review:
The Gamers Parable.

First of all, this text is not intended to offend anybody. I'm just putting out my view so people like me would understand what's going on and would not try this humiliation (of course in our perception). Because for me that was, so be wary of the number of good reviews for this game. Although we are the statistical minority in the gaming community I should warn my kind because ohh... this was harsh.

I personally see this game as an insult to people who've never before seen the extent humans could admire the breaking of the 4-eth wall. When it's done well - a lot of people really enjoy it for some strange reason. Like they are looking for not a world to immerse in but have a need for a world that would demonstrate attention to them and thus they would recognize the world as a real one. Unfortunately, in the world of gamers, a disability to empathize with fantasy to the extent of almost real-life experience is a common thing. I guess you could explain it through the socialization most of them had. A lot of people who dislike the outside and have a lot of time to play the games could be less empathetic than those who behave otherwise. Or maybe they wish to live another way but are afraid/physically incapable. So they will often perceive suffering as a normal part of life, for themselves and for others. Of course, no experience is necessary in cases of psychopathy and sociopathy, but those are exceptions in the population at present. No wonder, the game that laughs at your attempts and the wish to get the true ending encouriging you to do it at the same time but gives the satisfaction of the 4-eth wall breaking is "very positive" for most here.

No, thanks, I have vr games for the wall breaking where I need to and on demand. The Stanley Parable is a beautiful piece of manifestation of meaninglessness. The key is that a good story could be more immersive than a real one. And the true magic and potential of computer games are in the number of tools to make the story even more vibrant. A nice sound that matches the visual style, scriptwriters who are passionate to bring a new living experience for you, which allows you to grow as a human being, to fill your heart. This is the way I see story-rich games and this is a laugh at those who like stories regardless of the numbers of their dimensions.

125779866.review:
Download the demo 1st, or you may feel like you wasted your $$ as I did.  All the positive reviews must be from peeps with endless hours to devote playing the game over and over in hopes of some tiny difference to show up.  That is the game in a nutshell—walking down the same path over and over just to see what might (too often doesn't) happen differently.  

Granted, the concept is novel, and there is some humor at times, but it all equates to much exposure to great tedium of repetition for very little novelty/entertainment factor.  It's the perfect example of the concept of diminishing return.

125527077.review:
9/10

The Stanley Parable is a comedic creation contemplating how today's common workers, depicted essentially as mindless slaves, can escape a lifeless cycle of working for somebody else rather than themselves. 

There aren't many game mechanics, but that's not really why you buy this game. This game is 100 percent story focused alongside multiple player-made choices which alter the ending. The story is enjoyable, causing me to laugh many times, and feel senses of urgency, thoughtfulness, and somberness throughout my playtime. And considering the age of this game, it'll likely be optimized for your computer; I played this on a productivity laptop and received minor stuttering in render-heavy rooms. I also played this on the lowest graphic settings possible, excluding a 1920x1080 resolution.

I'd avoid buying this full retail considering there's The Stanley Parable: Deluxe Edition, but buying this on sale is worth it.

124363100.review: I had somehow escaped the clutches of the Stanley Parable for many years, despite it being 'one of those indie titles' that everyone has played at some point. I did not know much about the game, asides from its reputation for meta humour, and I was pleasantly surprised. Having come out in 2013, I can see how the game influenced many indie titles after its time, as well as the clear influences from the writing of Portal! I loved the clever use of the Narrator for witty, sometimes cynical, and overall philosophical narration, as the player is both given a feeling of no control and all the control. Being an overall annoyance, I obviously immediately did not do what I was told, leading to some fun, and also rather sinister outcomes for Stanley. I enjoy how there is so much subtle variety in playthroughs, although after getting the [spoiler] Museum Ending [/spoiler] I felt my motivation to unlock everything waning. I did enjoy the handful of endings I got, and left satisified with the fun little game I'd played. Stanley Parable does earn its place with the Indie greats for innovation, all I have left to do is not touch the game for the next few years...

124037558.review:
A genius comedy game through and through.

As far as gameplay it feels similar to being just a walking simulator, but you can interact with the world in multiple ways and it’ll change things from whips the narrator says, endings you get, to changing the world itself.

The game feels very self aware and it knows how to talk to many different types of players. If you follow along the plot blindly saying yes to everything, it’ll make fun of you. Try doing the opposite of what it says to do? You will be brutally teased. Do neither and try hard to find a third chaotic option where you derail the game entirely? You will be teased but it’ll go along with it more than you expect.
I think that’s what draws players to this game, if you think to yourself ‘can I do this weird side thing I just thought of?’ The answer is usually yes and it will lead to a long branching ending.
If you don’t find the game funny though I probably wouldn’t bother with it.
It’s a comedy game through and through, and the narrator is a constant.
While I find it hilarious I’m sure some might not.

Another thing I noticed, while I’m not sure how common my finding is, is that sometimes it downright feels like a horror game. Not sure if it’s just because I’m a literal baby, but sometimes quietly going through corridors and around corners, unsure of what you’ll find, the narrator going unusually quiet or talking in a creepy voice, can scare the hell out of me. I try to tell myself that this game holds no horror in it, but there are several moments in the game where I found myself exactly as tense as when playing an actual horror game, even leaving the game with a similar sense of fear.
Don’t get me wrong through, I love horror games and a creepy feeling, but finding it here was unexpected for sure.

Only con to the game is if you actually find every corner of the game and every quip it has to offer, it will lose its replayability fast. Unless you haven’t played it in years and you forgot most of it, it’s more of a short, singular experience. That being said, I think it’s an experience everyone should have.

122050507.review:
The Stanley Parable a game that wants to make you believe it is deeper than it actually is.

The game presents itself as a deconstruction of video games, making the player reflect on their choices, and on whether they have freedom of choice at all. The gameplay is simple, with you, some dude in an office, wandering about trying to figure out the situation he's been put in. You're followed by a narrator, who of course comments on everything you do.

The narrator is the means through which the 'point' of the game is established, that being the themes of choices in video games and even fate if you will. However, setting aside the fact that the narrator is unfunny and annoying, the themes that the game focuses on are nothing revolutionary. Even when the player controls Stanley (the protagonist) to do something that goes against the narrator's instructions, the player will find that the narrator still has relevant voicelines. This is meant to raise the question of whether the player really had a choice at all, relating to the themes mentioned earlier. 

However, I think that this theme falls flat in the game. Because of course you have a choice in games. For example, you can either go through the left door or the right door, even if there is some other force (like an annoying narrator) telling you to pick one over the other. However, although you can choose which door to go through, you cannot really pick the game ending you get, unless the game mechanic is very straightforward (i.e. 'good' choices = good ending, 'bad' choices = bad ending). The whole "what if you actually can't choose in vidya geam" thing the game tries to pull is stupid because obviously games plan for a player's choices, because it's in the fucking code. At the end of the day, you have to choose something, because that's how games work. In the Stanley Parable, you can choose your actions, just not the ending, because you're not a dev and obviously can't change the fucking game itself. I have a grand total of 66 minutes in this game, enough to get 2 different endings, but it took me about 5 minutes to figure out what the game was trying to do. I thought it was boring and pointless. Other games, and even other forms of media such as books or movies, have handled the idea of 'freedom of choice' in much more interesting and engaging ways than this game.

This of course ties in to the gameplay itself. I think the game is boring, and although I might be biased because I much prefer fast paced games with good combat, I fail to see how anyone could enjoy what is effectively a walking simulator with some guy commenting on your boring, dumb walking. The game is pretty much an interactive audiobook, except the book in question is some boring work you had to read in the 6th grade, dumb enough for even a 12 year old to understand. The game provides no new insight on the concept of freedom of choice, and certainly does not try to go beyond a surface-level analysis of the theme in question, much like a 12 year old writing an analytical essay on The Great Gatsby might do. Therefore, the game is uninteresting. This is not to say i do not enjoy dialogue heavy games. Although it may be a strange comparison, since rdr2 and Stanley are two very different games trying to achieve very different things, when sitting on my horse as Arthur for many minutes at a time listening to him and the other characters speak i never felt bored or uninterested, because the dialogue was actually engaging. In the Stanley parable however, all you have is the narrator talking at you for hours, which is great if you're having trouble falling asleep at night because it is just like one long class lecture. You could argue that rdr2 is different because there are more than two characters, but it is absolutely possible to write a single character monologuing and making their monologue actually interesting and engaging, which is something that the Stanley parable failed to do. 

Overall, i do not understand the praise that this game gets, and i certainly do not understand the people who say that it is revolutionary or thought-provoking. Maybe if i was a middle schooler i would think that way, but unfortunately, the passage of time is unstoppable. And again, the gameplay is pretty much just a walking simulator, and the smug narrator only adds insult to injury (although the voice acting is pretty good I'll give it that). At the end of the day though, the game is clearly not for me, and I'm sure that for others, they may consider this to be the best game of all time, somehow. That said, I would still strongly recommend people to please go play a game that actually has interesting dialogue and manages to explore it's different themes in provoking and engaging ways instead.

121336402.review:
The Stanley Parable is many things which are hard to describe, but at its heart it is an inquiry into how much choice a player truly has in a video game when all possible paths have been programmed ahead of time. This involves a sort of subtle exploration of the power dynamics between the creator and consumer of interactive art. The Stanley Parable is a walking simulator where the character's decision to follow or ignore the narrator's directions determines which of the many possible endings occur. Galactic Cafe does not seem to lay out a single authoritative claim on any of these matters and instead lets the player form their own thoughts on the matter after seeing the complex discussion laid out across the many endings. The art and music is simple, almost minimalist, but it is well suited to telling the branching story and carrying its messages. 

The Stanley Parable isn't just an art project though: it also seeks to entertain the audience through its absurd comedy. It's always funny to see how the narrator reacts when Stanley causes mischief by not doing what he is told to do. The sarcastic dialogue, surreal situations, and satirical observations add a dry, subtle humor to everything that manages to continually surprise you. I would heavily recommend The Stanley Parable to anyone interested in the philosophy of narrative design or creative approaches to comedy in video games. 

Also, the Broom Closet is ending is my favorite. I don't know why my friends find this concerning whenever I ask them if they got it too.

120535038.review:
This is the story of a man named Stanley. Stanley worked for a company in a big building where he was employee number 427. Employee number 427’s job was simple: he sat at his desk in room 427 and he pushed buttons on a keyboard. Orders came to him through a monitor on his desk, telling him what buttons to push, how long to push them, and in what order. This is what employee 427 did every day of every month of every year, and although others might have considered it soul 
rending, Stanley relished every moment that the orders came in, as though he had been made exactly for this job. And 
Stanley was happy... And then one day, something very peculiar happened, something that would forever change Stanley, something he would never quite forget. He had been at his desk for nearly an hour when he realised that not one, single order had arrived on the monitor for him to follow. No one had shown up to give him instructions, call a meeting, or even say hi. Never in all his years at the company had this happened, this complete isolation. Something was very clearly 
wrong. Shocked, frozen solid, Stanley found himself unable to move for the longest time, but as he came to his wits 
and regained his senses, he got up from his desk and stepped out of his office.

Otra vez aquí, ¿quién me habla? ¿Las directrices que narran esta historia por palabras?
Creo que estoy loco, debo morir! Resurgiré de nuevo en las llamas de una triste mordida de dramas...

Estoy aquí, eso lo sé, pienso, luego existo, el refrán del llamativo espectro circundante... Todo me rodea, no se nada, ¿qué es esto? Dímelo, voz! No paro de dar vueltas, voy a saltar! Saltaré! Aguante!

Otra... otra vez... pero algo es distinto,,, esta vez ya no me resulta un laberinto!! Se el camino! Aprendo! No bebo sino el más puro alcohol de vino tinto! Esto es real! Escaparé de este perdido recinto!

Pero una vez más, ¿datos? ¿códigos? ¿anonimatos? ¿hijos prodigos? ¿Mis hermanos?

Debo pulsar el botón, ¡saldré de aquí! ¡Esta furia desconcertante me penetra danzas falsantes!
No estoy loco, ¡lo juro! ¡Déjame en paz! Todo brilla ahora, es otra historia, una vez más, el ciclo sigue desesperado...


Esto es una parábola, eso está claro, hecha por un jefe, alto y raro, situado en amparo de esta total malicia de negro asfalto. aquí otra vez... acertaste novato... soy Stanley, un muñeco barato...

119284762.review:
To be upfront about this game, it's 30% pure gold and 70% to-do list. The gold in this game comes from the humor, and when it's funny, god-damn the game is funny. Almost every time the game made me laugh, I nearly had to put the controller down and hold my head in my hands. I couldn't even get the air out fast enough most of the time. But those moments are experienced once, and then probably not again, considering the layout of the game. And even if they were experienced again, well, jokes get stale the more you tell them.

As for the to-do list, following the Narrator or not following the Narrator, or purposefully contradicting the Narrator all amount to the same thing: you find an ending, and the game is restarted. Although you can "beat" the game, there is no winning. Hopefully in the last iteration you found some of that comedy gold, but in many of the paths you can take, you probably won't. Also there's a bajillion different endings to the game, and some of the endings require other endings to be completed first, and to find all the endings, you have to read the wiki as much as you would for a souls game or Elden Ring. So yeah, 70% to-do list.

The humor in this game, when you find it, is absolutely incredible, but to be honest, finding all the endings yourself is not going to happen unless you have way too much time on your hands, and reading the wiki takes the fun out of it. I haven't played the Ultra-Deluxe yet, but probably won't touch it for a few months until my lack of enthusiasm for this game fades. Like I said, there's no "winning" this game, and for anyone who's played this game, perhaps you'll understand when I say that the only winning move is not to play.

118618957.review:
This game has a truly wonderful narration by Stephen Fry. Stephen wrote a novel called "The Liar", an excellent book BTW. Stephen also lied about being called Kevan Brighting. It's a game with an unreliable narrator.
The office has whiteboards galore, with charts and quips that will bring a tear to the eye of even the most hardened Professional-Managerial Class veteran. Those whiteboards write about the usual stuff: the profit-chasing, the motivational mottos, and the coworkers who refuse to get out of the broom closet.
Have you ever played a game in which the narrator will keep sarcastically and hurtfully berating you just because you've chosen to stay inside the broom closet for longer than... longer than whatever is the time that normal people spend inside broom closets? You've played games that are self-conscious, but have you ever played a game that has the chutzpah to make you walk through an expansive, luxurious, and intricate museum [i]to itself[/i]?
You haven't, amigo, you haven't. So you will buy this game and you'll play it. Or you won't. And you'll be testing it for fall damage. Or you won't. And you'll be checking out its list of achievements to find the most preposterous one. Oh yes, you will.

118366381.review:
This game is about the ending, not the journey and oh boy do you journey and do nothing else...

You very quickly run through all the telegraphed stuff, hopefully you do it in a good order. I think i got a bad order... i got 0 payoff except for the [spoiler]museum[/spoiler] ending.

The one lone fact that this is a very boring game and is that the most fun you can have was walking in the [spoiler] museum where they showed stuff from development that never made that cut.[/spoiler]

This game is interesting and new experience for about an hour. Very interesting in fact because its novel one for me but then it falls off a damn cliff due to being the same thing over and over and over and over and over which starts to grate on your mind something fierce. Its loads and loads of wait time and repetitive walking until you may attempt a slight variation again at the end. Nothing ever changes in the journey. Its all at the end and often it doesnt really change anything except what you would expect if that makes sense?

Instead of an engaging experience you are filled with boredom knowing you have to wait through all the same stuff over and over and over and over and do the same stuff repetitively in hopes of maybe getting to a spot when you might get a new outcome if you slightly attempt something. Which is a horrific experience to me.

I wish the narration wouldnt start (or better yet have an indication) if it was something you had already heard once and already remember. What you enjoyed the first time, found ok the 2nd and 3rd time but at the 4th time and beyond started to actively hate what the game was doing. This really taints the experience.

Taking your time and exploring and looking around is not rewarded in any way from what I could tell and that is what I love about games. You can hardly interact with anything nor have an effect on anything except by slowly walking there. You press a button at an intersection and get one ending. Do the same shit again then get the second ending. You just suffer mental anguish in between every single attempt because there is nothing new happening in between. Just suffering.

118159144.review:
This is the review of a game called The Stanley Parable, and while I'd love to write the whole review as if I were the narrator, I lack the ingenuity and wit to do so, which is why I'll stop now, and proceed with a proper review. So, what is The Stanley Parable, you might be asking? Well, it's a game about choice, simple as that. However, while you might associate "choice" gameplay with games like Life is Strange, or with visual novels, this isn't like that.

No, The Stanley Parable is a first person game, and one of the earliest walking simulators. I've been a fan of this game (or is it a franchise now?) since its original mod release, and it's been great seeing it evolve over the years. The story is rather simple, or complex, depending on your choices. The game basically tells the story of Stanley, or Employee 427, who worked in an office. One day, he discovers that all his coworkers have disappeared, and thus decides to explore the office building in search of answers. As he moves through the office, he reaches the game's core: the two doors. A simple concept, choosing left or right, that this game manages to explore in incredible depth.

All throughout the game, there's a secondary character, the Narrator. As his name implies, he's the one narrating the story, and thus, guiding Stanley's (and the player's) actions. However, going back to the two doors mentioned above, the player can choose to ignore the Narrator and figuratively wrestle with him for control of the story, the more you progress through the game, the more options that begin to show up, leading to a great deal of replayability as you try to get all the different endings. All this accompanied by the Narrator's hilarious dialogue.

The writing is superb, and I can't state this with enough emphasis; while the only speaking character is the Narrator, as mentioned above, almost all his dialogue is hilarious, though there are some somber moments here and there. Visually speaking, it looks pretty good. The office's design has been updated from its mod release, and some new areas, related to new endings, have been added. Gameplay wise, it's very simple: you walk and interact with certain objects; as it is a very heavily story-driven game, there's not much else to do, no fancy shooting or parkour sections, but they aren't needed. Finally, the soundtrack, while minimalistic, serves its purpose well.

All in all, I can say I definitely recommend this game. Saying too much about it would spoil it, which is why I won't extend this review more than I have to.

A review of the game is a review of the self in that moment, this included.

118057988.review:
Una experiencia única en la que juegan contigo mientras se ríen de la vida y de sus ámbitos como pueda ser trabajar. Dentro reseña!

Como ya sabéis a mi me gusta dividir entre videojuegos y experiencias. Y esta es una experiencia cojonuda. Con un control simple de avanzar y un botón de acción nos ponemos en la piel de Stanley, un trabajador que debe seguir unas directrices en todo momento.

Por otro lado tenemos la figura del Narrador que nos va diciendo por dónde debemos ir, que puerta atravesar o que código ingresar. Pero la magia de todo esto es la sátira al trabajo. ¿De verdad quieres seguir las directrices o rebelarte contra el sistema?

Y es ahí donde viene una experiencia basada en toma de decisiones. Pero no a la decisiones en la que vemos un texto y nos acostumbran a elegir. Son decisiones narrativas que dependen de lo que hagamos. Pasar por una puerta o volver por donde hemos venido. Y entonces eso conlleva a MUCHOS finales, finales buenos, malos y regulares. Al final el narrador acaba siendo gracioso (voces en inglés y texto en español). Y la run que hagas tiene un principio (siempre desde el punto de inicio de la oficina) y un final que has decidido.

No puedo más que recomendarlo mil veces, no sé por qué no lo había "jugado" antes. Da igual si eres gamer, como si no, debes jugar stanley parable al menos una vez en la vida. En cuanto a la duración, el "final" como tal se puede sacar en 4 minutos.

De ti depende echarle las horas que quieras para descubrir todo lo que puedes hacer, que finales pueden deparar a Stanley y cuántos secretos contiene el lugar de trabajo del mismo. Vale el precio que sea, una joya de esas que no se te olvidan cuando el videojuego juega contigo.

Descubre todos los misterios alrededor del trabajo de Stanley y prueba a rechazar el sistema guiado, porque, ¿Qué mejor que llevar la contraria a todos y tomar tus propias decisiones, Stanley?. Gracias por leer! <3

117921402.review:
What a letdown! The other comments led me to believe there was something amazing about this game. But in the end it's so basic, what a missed opportunity, it could have been so much more! It's very hard to explain why I didn't like this game without spoiling it. So I'll use a metaphor to express my frustration (keep in mind it will still spoil you a little):

[spoiler]Imagine you enter a maze and you're excited to figure out this huge puzzle! But as soon as you enter you see that there is a straight path leading you all the way to... The exit. Sure there are other paths branching left and right from this straight line, but you can actually see the exit right there in front of you, so what's the point in wandering? You can litterally just walk less than 5 minutes and finish the game (and THAT is not a metaphor, there is an achievement for ending the Stanley parable in less than 4 minutes 20 seconds!). But back to our metaphor: so you walk straight and finish the game, leaving you with ony the slightest feeling of achievement (after all, you reached the end) but still thinking "wait, that's it?!". On top of that a sign at the end of the maze tells you "congratulations on beating the maze, but now try and discover who built this maze? and why? and how?"... Oh and suddenly you understand! That's the easy ending! There has got to be a hidden ending explaining everything and it's going to blow your mind! So you start the maze again but this time you go through aaaaall the other branching paths, thinking you will discover clues, or pieces of the story.

But to your surprise, all the other paths are dead ends! They lead nowhere and give you zero extra infos. Frustrated, you give up and look at a walkthrough, only to realize that... You have already encountered all the dead ends, and the walkthrough call those dead ends : "alternative endings". But they really are not alternative endings, they are dead ends, it's a big difference! So there is nothing to discover about this maze? The only interesting story was the straight path that takes less than 5 minutes?!

Want to know something even worse? Through the branching paths you will come acrosse 2 or 3 actual puzzles, and you will work on them over and over until the walkthrough tells you that... Nope! There is no answer actually! No matter what you do, you were bound to fail and reach another dead end...

Why didn't the devs put clues here and there as to what's going on, so we could reach a meaningful ending? It would not have been so hard, and it still would have left space for weird and confusing dead ends![/spoiler]

And it's really too bad, because the original idea was really fun. It made me all excited and I had fun "investigating", but if nothing is meaningful, well that's just lazy work I think. Hell, I could come up with an entire "story line" (it's not really a story line but you get my point) in a couple hours! I'm so glad I didn't buy the more expensive deluxe version, because digging deeper a bad design would have been even more frustrating.

And this version has secrets that the demo shares, unlike the Ultra Deluxe edition which doesn't have a dev console option and thus it's forever lacking a certain ending and most of the secrets. Ultra Deluxe does add some new ones and a new element that modifies the normal endings though so that's fun. Not to mention that Uktra Deluxe makes a reference to a joke that originates in the demo. I mean the normal game does too but UD takes it further. A blind playthrough is best at first, then do some research to find the other endings. There's approximately 19 endings in this.
