116744701.review:
Okay, I want to make two reviews here: one of the Stanley Parable Demo, and one of the Stanley Parable itself.

[h1] The Stanley Parable Demonstration [/h1]

The most important thing to note is that the Stanley Parable Demo is an entirely separate game from the Stanley Parable itself - the Demo contains its own separate narrative and content.

The story of the demo is of the Narrator trying to show the player the Stanley Parable Demo, to show them the wonders of the full game - but for some reason neither the Narrator nor the player can seem to find the Demo. This game has a lot of meta commentary - as standard for the Stanley Parable series. Most noticeably, the demo makes a big deal out of how it [i]fails[/i] to show you what the Stanley Parable is all about. And I think in all of that commentary, it perfectly showcases the Stanley Parable. Sitting in the waiting room, waiting for your number as the Narrator comments on it, or pressing the 8 button while the Narrator yells at you about how this is NOT the Stanley Parable - it tells the player, "do anything. We'll be ready for you."

I don't know if I have a whole lot else to say, outside of just one thing: this is, in my opinion, the best demo ever. Give it an award or something.

But of course, that's just the demo. Let's talk about...

[h1] The Stanley Parable (2013) [/h1]

Game of the millennium. What else can I say? 

The Stanley Parable is a ridiculously engaging game that I have no clue what genre to put it under - the best I can do is [i]"sandbox narrative."[/i] The game has some many endings, so many details all over the place, so much care and effort put into every single inch of this game. Not a single piece feels out of place, everything makes sense, everything feels [i]fantastic[/i]. Except the baby game. I have yet to actually do that ending myself, for obvious reasons.

The Stanley Parable is a game that sets you in a world, and tells you, "Go ahead. Write a story." One of the endings comments on the nature of the Stanley Parable, and games in general - the idea that every ending has been written, and so no matter what you're walking a path someone else set for you. And yet, the Stanley Parable never feels like that, never feels like you're being dragged along somebody else's story. This game is [i]yours.[/i]. You determine where to go, what to do. You're the one forging a new path, discovering new endings around every corner.

The Stanley Parable is a masterful mixture of comedy and literally anything else. The game is probably most well-known for its wonderful sense of humor, but the Stanley Parable has plenty of more serious moments. And it knows exactly what its supposed to be at any moment. Something amusing might flow smoothly into something soothing and calming, followed up by sorrow and tragedy. And every emotion is just... conveyed [i]so well.[/i] I love every moment of it - every joke, every insult, every single thing that happens. I could make a joke about the Broom Closet Ending being my favorite, but honestly... [i]every[/i] ending is my favorite. Every single one. They're all just fantastic.

The Stanley Parable is a work of art that holds a special place in my heart. A game that shows what games can be. A game that shows what life can be. A game that shows what the Stanley Parable is. It's beautiful.

The Stanley Parable is easily a 12/10, at minimum. That's with a lot of restraint - if I let myself say whatever I wanted to, it'd be a 1000000/10. 

The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe came out a month or two ago, and I played through it all. I won't be reviewing it yet, though - I'll review it in ten years, once I've got the achievement "Super Go Outside."

Galactic Cafe / Crows Crows Crows, thank you for making such wonderful masterpieces.

116444701.review:
The Stanley Parable is one of the most interesting games I have ever played in my life. The narrator is an anonymous, probably middle-aged man who narrates a story that YOU create, a story that YOU design and conclude.

You have always two paths or more to decide in this great game. The narrator always has a story in mind, therefore he narrates the entire time. There are multiple endings, so many to the point where it's actually still worth getting all of them. The achievements are an interesting concept, I haven't seen many games being this interesting in such storytelling as well.

Overall, The Stanley Parable is a must-have for any steam library. You should get it now if you haven't, and, if you want to, you should go get the demo. I was told by a friend to purchase this game and I don't regret it a single bit.

115977787.review:
I first played and beat The Stanley Parable on my brother's account years and years ago. This was a big deal for stories in games when it first came out, and it's still an incredibly enjoyable experience. After I beat the Ultra Deluxe Edition, I realized that I hadn't written a review for this, so here we are.

PROS:
+An easy enough premise to get started, written in such a way that regardless of how you play games, all it takes is (at max) two playthroughs to get what the game's about.
+A fantastic meta-commentary on video games as story-telling devices, well worth playing for anyone who likes stories in games.
+Kevan Brighting is a fantastic actor portraying The Narrator, a character who's still well-developed despite always being off-screen.
+A wide branch of endings with incredibly variety of getting to them and outcomes.
+The only game I've played (that I'm aware of) outside of Modern Warfare 2 with a proper museum providing interesting behind-the-scenes information and tidbits to enjoy.
+This game has an honest-to-God demo to see if you like it or not before you buy!
+The most comfortable broom closet in any game I've played.
+This is incredibly difficult to write about without getting into spoilers.
+Solid music and graphics.
+Regularly goes on sale for a reasonable price.
+Pleasantly-surprising cameos from other classic games!

CONS
-Some of the endings are ridiculous to get.
-Having beaten the Ultra Deluxe edition, I feel like that one's more valuable. This is still good if you're on a budget, but that one has literally everything in here and more.
-I mean, the humor isn't for everyone, but I thought it was funny.
-Likewise with the Narrator. Not everyone liked him, but I loved him.
-If you're a sucker for achievements, this one isn't exactly easy to get all of the achievements for, especially legitimately.
-Watching a Lets-Play on YouTube will spoil pretty much the whole thing.

Get the demo and see if it's for you. If it is: great! If not, that's okay too!

115347347.review: A really enjoyable walking simulator with a bunch of different endings, easter eggs and branching paths. I don't typically play many games of this genre so take my review with a grain of salt. The narrator(s) is the best part of the game by far. He is equally both doggedly charasmatic and unhinged. I know for a fact I didn't see everything there was to see in about 6 hours, however I certainly had my fill and I'm fine with that. It does a good job of keeping things fresh and not overstaying its welcome, although it can become monotonous if you let it.

115334968.review:
So after 3 hours, I hesitated to put out a positive or a negative review. 

TLDR : glad this game got made, very funny, but it's just not that deep sis

I started the game. I loved it, I laughed, I gasped. It was amazing for like 1 hour and a half. And then I ran out of ideas because I'm just not that good/dedicated, so I looked out for solutions online, because I was really interested in the story. 

And...It's a lot of redoing for not much more than what was in the first runs. Like it's not a coincidence if everyon keeps spamming the same jokes over and over again, this game has one very good idea, but then it doesn't really go anywhere with it.

So I'm really glad this exists, but I'm frustrated they didn't either 1°) make a shorter game, even if of course people would have gotten disappointed paying money for only 1 hour

or even better 2°) go further with their idea and really explore the implications of it instead of just making convoluted ways for finding jokes.

I'll probably keep going through the ending, and check the Beginner's Guide. The Stanley Parable moved me, albeit rarely,  it made me think, albeit not so much, so I still think it's worth playing this game. But it really could've been way better.

115227093.review:
From the Ashes of Depravity Rises the Phoenix of Quality

How else to describe The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe?

Such a revolutionary step forward in the lineage of one of the most beloved video game properties of all time! The additions and changes made to this expansion will surely resonate in the annals of the history of all media ever made. It is perhaps true to say that no mistakes are forever etched in stone, for the stone into which The Stanley Parable was carved has itself been transmuted, offering a message of hope to those who have ever erred in their judgement. You are not beyond redemption. You may change, and you may become more, so much more than you were before.

If there is any message to be taken from The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe, it is this...

What a fortune, a privilege, a joy it is to have had such an experience. It leaves me hopeful that as a community--as a world--there is time for us to become our greatest selves. As great as we ever could dream of in our wildest, most ambitious visions for a brighter future.

115216610.review:
The Stanley Parable is a wonderful experience for first time players, and the achievements, easter eggs, and mods (especially the Raphael Parable) give you some replay value. If you don't mind a game that you'll get at most 20 hours of before you never play again, The Stanley Parable is great.

If replay value is a must, you hate mindfuck games, and you can't stand non-open-world games, avoid this like the plague, but otherwise, playing this game is a must-have experience.

One final thing: don't make the same mistake I did. Play it before watching YouTubers play it—discovering the story is 3/4 the fun of it, and watching it beforehand will just ruin it for you.

The Stanley Parable...

Después de mucho tiempo de estar pensando aún estoy pensando en las palabras para poder expresar lo que sentí al jugar este juego.

La primera vez que lo jugué me entro curiosidad por ver lo que el juego escondía, mientras iba jugando me iba sorprendiendo con las cosas que pasaban ya que eran totalmente inesperadas. Todos los desafíos que tiene para poder hacer.
Me gusta como el juego puede jugar con las cosas de su "mundo" por así llamarlo. Cada vez que se reinicia tienes ganas de ver que hubiera pasado y presionabas otro botón o elijes otra puerta.

El juego lo recomiendo mucho a todas la personas, no importa si no te llaman la atención este tipo de juegos. Te invito a que le des una oportunidad y si decides seguir jugando o no será por parte tuya. Es divertido, te motiva a seguir descubriendo lo que tiene. 


Gracias por leer ^^

114914831.review:
Be advised that ~95% of the content from this game did make it faithfully into the Ultra Delux version which is separately purchasable on Steam, and that UD has tons of additional .. uh .. game in the game, as well as far higher texture resolution and native 4K (and possibly higher, but I can personally vouch for 4K) support.

All of that said though, if you are the completionist type of person or if you're interested in messing with the steam console in the game (I was personally surprised to learn after playing a ton of UD that it's not even on the same engine any more!) and especially if you would like to see the 5% of content that was left out of the port to UD (tbf, some of which involves the above-mentioned console)... or if you are just really, really interested in the "classic" storyline(s) prior to having extra and more self-referential stuff to stumble into, then getting this one absolutely makes sense.

If you haven't played any of them yet and don't even quite know what I'm talking about, def play the free demo first. And if you are a completionist who just wants to see All Of The Things(tm) then you ought to play the free demo anyway, as it is a legitimate standalone mini-me amuse boosh of the main game(s) with no overlapping content at all: it's own short story.

Q: Wait, aren't you the guy who didn't like "The Beginner's Guide" by the same game maker?
A: That is true, I did find TBG to be a disappointing immersive experience relative to this franchise and I stand by that assessment. But that is primarily down to TSP (and the demo) setting the bar of expectation as high as it does. The Ultra Delux expansion does a fine job living up to this expectation for me though.

Think of it this way: The Beginner's Guide wouldn't honestly lose all that much impact if it were made into a film instead. The story is both sufficiently linear and indifferent to player action to survive that transition mostly intact. The Stanley Parable on the other hand.. even it's demo.. has no way to be transitioned that way. Non-linearity aside, it trolls and implicates and gaslights the player. It leads you to make gameplay decisions that genuinely make you the butt of digital practical jokes.

It doesn't just break the fourth wall, it replaces it with a genuine Wile-E-Coyote mural of a tunnel.

114910482.review: Hilarious. This is a must have.

114910443.review:
This game belongs in a museum.  

It's a perfect example of how video games can be a medium for high art.  The Stanley Parable will challenge your understanding of every game format you've ever encountered.  The unreliable, yet seemingly friendly, narrator will quickly become your adversary.  You will inevitably discover that difference between "playing" The Stanley Parable and "trying to break" The Stanley Parable is just a matter of perspective.  

This game is gold, and it's a rabbit hole.  Players who have the curiosity to dive in will be rewarded.

114689136.review:
This is a part of my review on the game without the " extra content " stuff

for starters, the papers scattered on the floor, one of them at least( I am not sure if it was on the floor or on a desk tbh ) had the word "God" on it, and I am not going step over a paper like that be it in real life or a video game. This is the main reason why I asked for a refund.
If you didn't figure it out by now, I am a Muslim and English is not my first language. However, I will still try my best to explain why I don't recommend the game. Or in fact, why I hate it

Before I knew this, I played a bit of the game, so shall we start?

One of the endings really send a great message of how you could waste your time playing video games, it is viewed by the narrator describing how pathetic "Stanley" is, pushing buttons... Wasting his time on this worthless tasks..
During this sequence, you are shown buttons on a screen and you must press it if you wish for the narrator to continue his monologue...

What really clicks in this sequence is this line from the narrator:
"But Stanley chose it" (paraphrasing)

You know, it is quite obvious that the game is sending a message, you are wasting your time playing video games, and for what?

But this message falls flat when the game itself is a paid product and I really don't think the creator really means those words, the ending does not have any meanings when you are expected to still play the game, you know, I will say it:
I did not play the full ending, when I got to the part which I just quoted I think I restarted the game and was really thinking of refunding it right then and there, but ultimately I decided to still wait and see

FYI: I knew the original and played it long ago, but that ending didn't hit with me the same at the time as I wasn't really going to question the use of my time. However, now that I am older, ( and consumed a lot of anti-gaming material hahaha) that clicked with me... Cannot say the same for the "jokes"

How do people find the "broom closet ending" funny is beyond me.
How did I find the "confusion ending" funny is really ... I don't know what to say

the humor of this game is childish, "oh, we don't have a store, let's make our own one with this trusty trusty adventure line! Oh no! The adventure line blah blah" is this whole section stolen from a script of a cheesy children cartoon or what?

"Oh, go right, no no it was left, well I am positive it was right here let me review the script" (again, paraphrasing)

114676793.review:
How do you review a game like The Stanley Parable? To describe any one part of it is to risk its ruination. To detail what it has to say about game design, the illusion of choice, and the psychology of the gamer is to tell you too much.

Comparisons, too, are going to be woefully inadequate. Perhaps its closest cousin would be Dear Esther, but where Dear Esther wastes the form of interactive entertainment, Stanley Parable uses and then subverts it. Where so many games that aspire to be more than games end up less than any form of art, Stanley Parable strives, and then succeeds, to be every game ever created. Even so, holding the game to the standards of any other title is simply not going to be correct.

So, how do you review what has become known as The Stanley Parable HD, the full-scale reimagining of one of the most intriguing mods available online? How do you discuss it, analyze it, and recommend it?

That’s quite simple.

You don’t.

(Joke implied.)

Man, this game... Ok first of all: I believe I played and/or watched every single ending of this game, but I can assure you that I wouldn't bet on that. I wouldn't be surprised if there's an ultra-secret-ending that I missed cause thats just how Stanley Parable works. Now moving on to the actual game: Play It. Thats it, I can't remark enough how much you have to play this game if you love the world of videogames. This sh*t is a brainfu**er. I mean it ok? I can't talk about this game cause it have so much to talk about and at the same time it doesn't have anything to talk about.
Ok but it isn't perfect thats for sure. The graphics are old and the controls are just 5 keys (walk and interact). Now, are those bad things? Debatible, the graphics are old but they aren't Rogue kind of old. They are maybe a bit modern than the Portal/Half-Life graphics so I believe it have something I will call "The Old Valve Charm". And about the controls, you dont need anything else to enjoy this game so don't complain.
Now, I know that all I said was really ambiguous but you HAVE to believe me when I tell you that I can't talk about this game. Being a bit more concrete about the game: I would compare it to the Zelda BoTW experience, meaning that every person will have a different experience playing it. The game have a great mechanic of changing little stuff with every restart, and it remembers your last plays and endings, kinda like Undertale. The difference of Undertale and BoTW with The Stanley Parable is that the last one doesn't have battles, a big cast or anything like that. It's just You, Stanley and The Narrator, and that is enough. The Stanley Parable Experience is unique and great and if you can you should probably play it. It's not expensive (neither in money nor system requirements). This Game is excellent and every person who really enjoys video-games should play it.
8.5/10, see y'all in five years.

114637039.review:
Stanley is an employee at an unnamed office, with the comically simple job of pressing the buttons he is ordered to via his computer screen. In that sense, his life isn't much different to that of a video game player, making you the perfect candidate to be him (and/or not be him, as the Steam description claims). One day, Stanley realises he's stopped receiving orders. For a brief moment, the forces controlling his every move have disappeared. What will Stanley do next?

Itching to find out is the story's Narrator, whose luxurious purring voice steps in to try and tell you which buttons to press now. He holds the key to Stanley's freedom; all you have to do is play out the story as he narrates it. I hope it's an open secret by now, though, that playing along is mostly optional, and silently discouraged. Spend too long admiring scenery and the Narrator will grumblingly assure you that there's nothing to see. Disobey any narration and you start down the road of any of 19 different branching paths, as the Narrator reacts to your behaviour by dramatically reshaping the story. He can play any part, from cold-hearted antagonist to well-intentioned supporter. He may even criticise the player directly (The Stanley Parable isn't interested in gaming trivia like inventory systems, the ability to jump, or the fourth wall). This is because, the way I see it, the Narrator is a game developer, and each interaction in the game has something to say about the cat-herding activity of game design, and possibly more deeply about culture, storytelling and personal agency in general. Where many developers would convey this through the medium of pretentious navel-gazing, here it's all couched in so much quality humour and spectacle that the game is simply entertaining on whatever level you want to engage with it.

This is easily one of the funniest games in my Steam library. I am essentially a captive audience for anything this team creates in the future. So much game humour leans on unoriginal references and puns, so it's very refreshing for a team to spin such consistently great comedy from its own premise. On rare occasions, the humorous presentation can work against the game a bit. Some more abrupt endings struck me as unpolished content on the developers' part more than jokes. For these to be the only jokes that don't land in the entire game is nevertheless a stunning achievement. The same comic voice can be found in Crows Crows Crows' newsletter, social media and hilariously meta promotional videos for the game, and will probably live on as straight forward quotes with no added comedic value in YouTube comment sections forever.

Unlike the rather controlling Narrator, the actual game's actual developers know that, as frustrating as it may be, the correct response to natural human curiosity is not to stifle it, but to indulge it. The explicit binary choices presented to you are the bulk of the interactivity but some of the best content is gated off to only the most determined players. When you think you've found every ending and Easter egg, you probably haven't, so be sure to look up the rest online at some point because they are not to be missed. That said, I don't think players should aim to see all the endings in one go and be done with it. This mindset commodifies the endings and makes them harder to appreciate - plus by the end of my time with it, 19 branches actually felt like a rather small number. It's best to savour this game; perhaps take the advice of its notorious "Go Outside" achievement and put off playing half the game for five years (which, it turns out, is not long enough to forget most of the events and experience the game like new).

The Stanley Parable retains some of the frugal spirit of the original 2011 mod for Half-Life 2, but thankfully uses brand new assets, stamping a unique visual identity onto the concept and turning that barren office into a gaming icon. The vacant setting softens the ground so that you're intrigued when you notice something out of place, or bowled over when something really surprising happens. Satirical corporate nonsense and extra dialogue scattered all over are very tempting to find and read, though you risk wrecking the pacing for yourself. The voice acting is addictive to listen to and I was happy to pay that price to fully hear every line I came across. The original soundtrack is flawless, despite the game sort of pretending to be low-budget.

I've described everything very vaguely in this review to avoid spoiling anything major. I have to admit that its style is bound to put some people off, but give it a go for one playthrough and you'll know if it's for you. I say this forensically self-aware meta-game is REQUIRED READING for anyone remotedly interested in interactive storytelling and an easy recommendation even if you just want a toy to make you laugh. Games have played with similar ideas before and since, but none hit all the notes like The Stanley Parable.

114593839.review:
[h1]THE STANLEY PARABLE[/h1]
[b]Originally a 2011 Award-Winning Half-Life 2 Mod remade into a full game running on Source.

You will play as Stanley, and you will not play as Stanley. You will follow a story, you will not follow a story. You will have a choice, you will have no choice. The game will end, the game will never end. Contradiction follows contradiction, the rules of how games should work are broken, then broken again. This world was not made for you to understand. The End is Never The End is Never the End is Never The End.

I highly recommend The Stanley Parable to anyone who wants a fun, interesting, mysterious and mind bending Narrative driven puzzle game. Simply put its one of the best games of all time and truly shows what an Indie game can be. Go play it and experience it for yourself...or don't...the choice is your's afterall[/b]

De entre las cenizas de la depravación, surge el fénix de la calidad. ¿De qué otra forma se puede describir The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe?

Es un revolucionario paso adelante en la estirpe de uno de los videojuegos más queridos de la historia. Los cambios y las novedades de esta expansión quedarán grabados en los anales de la historia de todas las creaciones.
Quizá se pueda decir que no hay error que quede por siempre grabado en piedra, pues la piedra en la que se talló The Stanley Parable ha sido transmutada para ofrecer un mensaje de esperanza a quienes han cometido errores de juicio.

Estás a tiempo de redimirte. Puedes cambiar, puedes convertirte en más, en muchísimo más de que lo eras antes. Si hay que quedarse con un mensaje de The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe, es este...

Qué fortuna, qué privilegio, qué alegría es haber gozado de una experiencia así.
Me da esperanza de que como comunidad, como mundo, aún estamos a tiempo de alcanzar nuestra mejor versión, una versión a la altura de nuestras fantasías más ambiciosas, para tener un futuro más brillante.

114578548.review:
[h1] Recommended cause its a good game. But do yourself a favor and buy the Ultra Deluxe version instead [/h1]

Stanley Parable when it came out sparked a big discussion on what constitutes a game. Technically there isn't really a loss state. You start the game and can do whatever you want, hell you could probably finish the game within 1 minutes if you tried for it. So what makes this fun, to me its the fact that you can reach an ending within 1 minute. The game really tests the boundaries of what you can do in a 3D game with barely any complicated mechanics at all. Behind the scenes a lot of stuff is going on, but the player has to work for it to find those secrets. That effort and choice to me is what makes me confidently say that this is a great game. After about 1 and a half hours I personally got bored of pushing those boundaries to find secrets, but I think that small amount of time was packed with a lot of content. And seeing other peoples play times it is very clear this game can be a lot longer if you want it to. To me even nowadays this is a fantastic game worth experiencing, at least I would say that if it wasn't for the newly released Ultra Deluxe version.

My first impressions from the Ultra Deluxe version is that its just this game but with more content, and some old content changed. The Stanley parable is all about exploring your own creativity and seeing what you can do, more content just results in a much more varied and open game. As a result it becomes hard to recommend the original. Its still a great game but I heavily recommend you buy the Ultra Deluxe version.

My only other complaint is the lack of Elden ring References. Something the Ultra Deluxe version thankfully fixes.
